docs.snippet: IT was the pain in her feet that finally persuaded Vicki Daly Redholtz to seek help 12 years ago. The combination of shooting pains and numbness intensified at night, Ms. Redholtz, a 58-year-old travel consultant in Culver City, Calif., recalled. She...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT was the pain in her feet that finally persuaded Vicki Daly Redholtz to seek help 12 years ago. The combination of shooting pains and numbness intensified at night, Ms. Redholtz, a 58-year-old travel consultant in Culver City, Calif., recalled. She began by consulting a podiatrist, who sent her for numerous tests over several months, but her condition was not diagnosed until an alert technician recognized her symptoms: Type 2 diabetes. Looking back, Ms. Redholtz realizes now that she had exhibited many of the classic warning signs of Type 2 diabetes, the most common form of the disease, for a long while. At the time she received the diagnosis, she was 46 years old, about 25 pounds overweight and had a strong family history of diabetes. For several years before the diagnosis was made, she had been unusually thirsty and seemed to be constantly going to the bathroom.

headline.main: With the Increase in Type 2 Diabetes Comes a Focus on Its Warning Signs

docs.snippet: STARTING as early as age 12 or 13, Wendi Perez remembers having abdominal troubles.    ''I would get cramping,'' said Ms. Perez, 32, an administrative manager in the Bronx. ''In my late teens the pain progressed, but in my 20's it got a lot worse....
docs.lead_paragraph: STARTING as early as age 12 or 13, Wendi Perez remembers having abdominal troubles. ''I would get cramping,'' said Ms. Perez, 32, an administrative manager in the Bronx. ''In my late teens the pain progressed, but in my 20's it got a lot worse. I'd get this rumbling in my lower abdomen and a burst of pain. Sometimes I'd break out in a cold sweat and want to throw up.''

headline.main: Among This Ailment's Symptoms: Acute Embarrassment

docs.snippet: ''BREAST is best'' -- that is what health care providers and advocates tell mothers who are making decisions about how to feed their newborns.    What is usually meant by that statement is this: compared with bottle feeding, breast-feeding offers...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''BREAST is best'' -- that is what health care providers and advocates tell mothers who are making decisions about how to feed their newborns. What is usually meant by that statement is this: compared with bottle feeding, breast-feeding offers incomparable benefits to children, even to those fed that way for a relatively short time. Among the benefits are reduced risks of asthma, lymphoma, sudden infant death syndrome, meningitis, pneumonia, inflammatory bowel disease, allergies, infections, diarrhea and colds. In a majority of studies, breast-fed children have I.Q.'s 3 to 10 points higher than children who are nursed by the bottle.

headline.main: Babies Aren't the Only Beneficiaries of Breast-Feeding

docs.snippet: ''I'M too fat.''    If there were a Hall of Adolescence, where the struggles of teenage girls were commemorated, those words might be inscribed over the door.
docs.lead_paragraph: ''I'M too fat.'' If there were a Hall of Adolescence, where the struggles of teenage girls were commemorated, those words might be inscribed over the door.

headline.main: How to Talk to Teenage Girls About Weight? Very Carefully

docs.snippet: ON a fiercely hot summer day, I was trudging from the Broadway subway toward my gynecologist's office. Sweat was running down my cheeks, and the tarry sections of the street were soft underfoot.    What am I doing? I asked my 82-year-old self. Just...
docs.lead_paragraph: ON a fiercely hot summer day, I was trudging from the Broadway subway toward my gynecologist's office. Sweat was running down my cheeks, and the tarry sections of the street were soft underfoot. What am I doing? I asked my 82-year-old self. Just because my doctor wants to administer an annual Pap test doesn't mean I have to put myself through anything this unpleasant.

headline.main: You're Never Too Old for a Pap Test, She Learns

docs.snippet: THE sign in the window of the New York Sports Club in Princeton, N.J., is hard to miss: ''Exercise reduces the risk of cancer.'' Not to mention the risk of saggy butt.    How perfect. First you get the health message. Even overstating the case, it...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE sign in the window of the New York Sports Club in Princeton, N.J., is hard to miss: ''Exercise reduces the risk of cancer.'' Not to mention the risk of saggy butt. How perfect. First you get the health message. Even overstating the case, it sounds as if it is your obligation to exercise. Then you get the message that addresses your secret reason for wanting to work out.

headline.main: Don't Sweat the Reasons, Just Go On and Sweat

docs.snippet: NINE years ago, when Dr. Kathrin U. Jansen began trying to create a vaccine to protect women against cervical cancer, other scientists gave her about a 10 percent chance of success. Some of her own colleagues at Merck Research Laboratories shook...
docs.lead_paragraph: NINE years ago, when Dr. Kathrin U. Jansen began trying to create a vaccine to protect women against cervical cancer, other scientists gave her about a 10 percent chance of success. Some of her own colleagues at Merck Research Laboratories shook their heads. Even a job applicant whom she interviewed took it upon himself to tell her that her idea would never work. (He did not get the job.) At conferences where she talked about the project, she felt waves of skepticism from the audience. ''That gives you even more energy,'' Dr. Jansen said.

headline.main: The Cross-Country Duo Behind a Breakthrough Vaccine

docs.snippet: ''DID you know that it's Beautiful Women Month?'' a much-forwarded e-mail message asks, before making a few pertinent statements. Here's a sampling: ''Marilyn Monroe wore a size 14''; ''If Barbie was a real woman, she'd have to walk on all fours'';...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''DID you know that it's Beautiful Women Month?'' a much-forwarded e-mail message asks, before making a few pertinent statements. Here's a sampling: ''Marilyn Monroe wore a size 14''; ''If Barbie was a real woman, she'd have to walk on all fours''; and ''The average woman weighs 144 lb. and wears between a 12-14.'' There are more ''facts on figures,'' not all of them perfectly accurate. Ms. Monroe, who was 5 feet 5 1/2 inches and weighed between 118 to 135 pounds, may have been busty enough to fill out a size 14, but partly because sizes were smaller in the 1950's. And Barbie is indeed disproportionate -- a 1995 study found that for a woman with an average body type to attain Barbie's shape, she would need to grow 24 inches (making her more than 7 feet tall), take 6 inches off her waist and add 5 to her chest. But if she came to life, she could presumably still walk upright, the director of the study said.

headline.main: One Size Definitely Does Not Fit All

docs.snippet: ABOVE a Duane Reade pharmacy in Washington Heights, the heavily Hispanic neighborhood in northern Manhattan, the Monday afternoon aerobics class at the Big Gym attracts women of all ages. Most are immigrants from the Dominican Republic, and many are...
docs.lead_paragraph: ABOVE a Duane Reade pharmacy in Washington Heights, the heavily Hispanic neighborhood in northern Manhattan, the Monday afternoon aerobics class at the Big Gym attracts women of all ages. Most are immigrants from the Dominican Republic, and many are overweight for the usual reasons, not the least of which is the Caribbean country's diet of rice, tubers, beans and meat -- and no qualms about deep-frying. The session is conducted in shrill, energetic Spanish by Jennifer Gonzalez, a faux-blonde Dominican whose classes are set to a merengue beat. The song of choice today is ''Todo el Mundo en Cuero,'' which means ''Everybody Get Naked.'' Nobody heeds the song's plea, although some undoubtedly wish they could. On clear afternoons, the sun glares through the room's huge third-floor picture windows, heating the place like the sauna that does not exist. There are no blinds, and air-conditioning is a pipe dream: a sign saying it was to be installed ''as soon as possible'' was posted for more than a year.

headline.main: At the Big Gym, Few Frills, but Plenty of Determination

docs.snippet: MORE than half of American women are overweight or obese, and as they age they are likely to get fatter and unhealthier. But despite this seemingly unstoppable trend, an increasing number of nutrition and weight experts are offering what may seem...
docs.lead_paragraph: MORE than half of American women are overweight or obese, and as they age they are likely to get fatter and unhealthier. But despite this seemingly unstoppable trend, an increasing number of nutrition and weight experts are offering what may seem surprising advice: never mind thin -- just get real and lose a little weight. It could be called the 10 percent solution: in recent years a steady stream of research has found that losing as little as 10 percent of body weight, or sometimes even less, has a disproportionately positive effect in improving health. Small weight losses significantly reduce the risk of a wide range of illnesses that have been linked to obesity, from heart disease and diabetes to some kinds of cancer.

headline.main: The 10 Percent Solution: Losing a Little Brings Big Gains
